title: Why were the 1970's and 1980's considered 'the dark years' for American automobiles? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not all American cars were bad for all of the 1970’s and 80’s, but many were, for sure. Back in the day, I was a Mopar fan, my 1972 car was something like this but without the fancy paint job.  This body style, 1971–1972 was used on several models, the best of which was the Roadrunner, and available with an obscenely powerful range of engines. Consequently it became the darling of the track as well and was the most popular body style for a full decade of racing.  But that was early in the decade. Then came the gas crisis of 1973, and another in 1979, and there was a sudden rush of interest in economy cars. Unfortunately American car makers didn’t have much experience in building smaller cars, so they hacked things together in very amateurish ways. That’s the real answer to your question. Among the worst was Ford’s treatment of the Mustang. The 1971 Ford Mustang Mach I was a very cool, very powerful beast of a car, sure to get any enthusiast’s blood moving.  However what followed just a couple years later was a horrible embarrassment of a car, the post-gas crisis “second generation mustang” produced from 1973 to 1978. It had been emasculated, gonads completely removed. Shamefully they even labeled some of them “Mach 1” when it was really only a rebadged Pinto (yes, really). Not even suitable as a young secretary’s first car.  But to be fair, there were many terrible cars from foreign auto makers of the period as well. Here’s a 1970’s Volkswagen “Thing” for instance:  And possibly the most hated car of all time, the Yugoslavian “Yugo” car produced from 1977–1988  And most Japanese cars of the 1970’s weren’t very good either. People used to laugh if you were driving a Toyota Corona or Corolla. They were small, tinny, unstylish, and they rusted out quickly.

Because the EPA had enacted pollution controls that the US auto market didn’t know how to meet without killing performance. Add to that an OPEC oil crisis or two, and insurance companies refusing to insure “muscle cars” at the same reasonable rates they had in the 1960s, and you’ve got the Cliff’s Notes version of the Malaise Era. Detroit still favored large, pushrod V8s, which actually had a lot going for them: they made a lot of HP (and equally important, torque) for very reasonable cost. This worked fine, so long as you didn’t really care about emissions. And, until the 1970s, nobody did. But throw in emissions as a concern, and those big V8s had a big problem! Today, of course, you’d use a proper 3-way cat and EFI, and you’d have the best of both worlds. Unfortunately, neither of these technologies were “ready for prime time” in the 1970s: EFI wasn’t yet precise or reliable enough, and catalytic converters didn’t yet treat NOx pollutants, although they had to be accounted for, generally by reducing compression ratio to keep cylinder temps down. Finally, there was a toxic culture at the top of the Big Three in Detroit. Read On a Clear Day, You Can See General Motors for a more thorough explanation. Short version: domestic automakers (GM in particular) had gotten too big, and too traditional, to innovate effectively; the emphasis was less on “beating the competitor in the market” and more on winning intra-departmental power struggles; GM looked like a (profit-driven) version of the Politburo. As a result of the above, there were hungry, Japanese motorcycle makers (one still chafed at calling Honda a “car company”) that were willing to take engineering risks Detroit wasn’t. Also (and for engineering reasons I won’t get into) the experience they had in smaller motorcycle engines led them to make OHC engines, whose “pentroof” designs naturally made lower emissions than the “wedge head” geometry a OHV design most easily favored. The stratified-charge, “CVCC” engine met emissions without a cat, and was a very notable “shot across the bow” of GM. But the ultimate answer to “how do you get performance without emissions?” was “computing power.” Only well-developed sensors, run by more powerful computers than the 1970s had to offer, would allow the precise control of the air/fuel mixture necessary to allow such a balancing act. While emissions controls were “a good thing in the long run,” they created almost a generation of poorly-running cars trying to meet “new world emissions” with “old world technology” like carbs, and mostly failing.
